media.caption: Machine learning’s evolution: Two decades of progress.

text.headline: Machine Learning 2000 - 2022
text.text: A visual timeline of Machine Learning from 2000 to 2022 — showing key milestones like early neural networks, top researchers, platforms like Kaggle, tools like Kinect, big datasets, and powerful models like ChatGPT.

media.caption: University of Montreal researchers published "A Neural Probabilistic Language Model," which suggested a method to model language using feed-forward neural networks.

text.headline: A Neural Probabilistic Language Model
text.text: authored by researchers at the Université de Montréal—notably Yoshua Bengio, Réjean Ducharme, Pascal Vincent, and Christian Jauvin—and it proposed modeling language using a feed‑forward neural network, introducing the now‑classic technique of learning distributed word representations alongside a neural network to predict word sequences.

media.caption: First open source machine learning library

text.headline: Torch
text.text: Open-source machine learning library and scientific computing framework developed by the Idiap Research Institute at EPFL. It utilizes the Lua programming language, specifically LuaJIT, to provide high-performance interfaces to deep learning algorithms implemented in C.

media.caption: A Free, All‑In‑One Platform for Data Science Learning, Collaboration, and Competition

text.headline: Kaggle
text.text: Kaggle is an online community and platform founded in 2010 (now part of Google) that enables data scientists to collaborate, share datasets, compete in machine learning challenges, and run code in cloud-based notebooks powered by free GPUs and TPUs. Users get a weekly allocation—typically 30 hours of GPU time and 20 hours of TPU time—for building, training, and experimenting within a ready-to-use environment. Its scoring and medal systems place users on public leaderboards, fostering learning, visibility, and career opportunities through recognition and performance.

media.caption: Microsoft's Kinect: Revolutionizing Gaming with Motion-Sensing Technology

text.headline: Kinect
text.text: Microsoft's Kinect, released for the Xbox 360 in November 2010, was a groundbreaking motion-sensing device that enabled controller-free gaming and interaction. It utilized a combination of hardware and software to track human movement and respond to voice commands, offering a new level of immersion in gaming and entertainment.

media.caption: Schmidhuber’s team built the first CNN to beat humans at visual recognition

text.headline: First Superhuman Visual Pattern Recognition
text.text: A team led by Jürgen Schmidhuber—together with Dan Claudiu Ciresan, Ueli Meier, and Jonathan Masci—built a type of deep learning model (a convolutional neural network) that beat human performance at recognizing traffic signs. In the 2011 IJCNN Traffic Sign Recognition contest, their model made just 0.56% mistakes, which is about half the error rate of people, who made 1.16% mistakes on average. This was not only better than humans but also clearly ahead of other computer methods.

media.caption: AI models that create realistic data using two competing networks.

text.headline: Generative Adversarial Network
text.text: It’s a type of AI that can create new data, like images or text. It was introduced in 2014 by Ian Goodfellow. GANs work by using two networks: one makes fake data (the generator), and the other tries to tell if it's real or fake (the discriminator). They compete with each other, helping the system get better over time.

media.caption: Artificial Intelligence Model that can generate images when you feed it textual descriptions.

text.headline: DALL·E
text.text: DALL·E is an AI model developed by OpenAI that can generate images from textual descriptions. It was introduced in 2015 and is based on the GPT-3 architecture. DALL·E can create a wide variety of images, from realistic photos to imaginative illustrations, all based on the prompts it receives.

media.caption: An AI chatbot that chats like a human.

text.headline: ChatGPT – OpenAI's Conversational AI Chatbot
text.text: ChatGPT is a conversational AI chatbot developed by OpenAI. It became very popular, getting over 1 million users in just five days. It can answer questions, write stories, and even help with coding. People use it for fun, learning, and getting help with different tasks. ChatGPT is known for its ability to understand and generate human-like text, making it a useful tool for many applications.
